title.narrative: OGB C&F Program Facilitation & Cap Bldg

description.narrative:
This project falls under the thematic area Conflict and Fragility (ToC). Through the work on ToC Conflict and Fragility Oxfam GB and SOMO aim to achieve that more marginalized groups have a say in policies that affect their lives; governments and international institutions support inclusion of women and promote protection of marginalized groups in security and peace building; and the private sector contributes to peace and development.
Within this Theory of Change, this project in Myanmar aims that communities that are directly impacted by private investment influence decision-making that positively impacts their human security. It seeks to ensure that private sector development in Myanmar contributes to improved human security, increased participation, public support for democratic transition, reduced conflict, and equitable, sustainable economic development for the women and men of Myanmar.
The proposed project posits that change will only take place through building trust and meaningful engagement within and between stakeholders, and the relevant private sector actors making commitments and steps towards responsible and conflict sensitive business practices. Oxfamin Myanmar#s theory of change for this project is structured in a way that all activities work towards providing the capacity, empowerment and groundwork necessary for meaningful and constructive engagement. The project will facilitate that Myanmar alliance for Transparency and Accountability (MATA) member CSOs and community leaders(male and female) have increased knowledge and capacity to constructively engage with private sector on the impact of investment on conflict affected communities. With this increased capacity we assure better coordination, collaboration and engagement between and within civil society stakeholders and government on a national and State/regional level regarding responsible and conflict sensitive investment.
Oxfam#s main partner will be MATA, which supports the most credible civil society alliance working ontransparency and accountability. It comprises of over 450 civil society actors and individuals from all of Myanmar#s 13 states and regions, and has grown from its original role to support civil society engagement in the EITI (Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative) in the country.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam great Britain is managing Oxfam in Myanmar. It has an office in Yangon since 2009 and operates in 5 townships as stipulated in its MOU with the Ministry of Agriculture and Irrigation.
Oxfam’s vision for Myanmar is for all citizens, including women and ethnic nationalities, to be able to enjoy their social, cultural, economic, civil and political rights. We believe it is possible for Myanmar to be led by a government that is responsive and accountable to its citizens; to have a political system everyone can be part of and have a dynamic private sector which works in the interests of the poorest. The focus of our work is now:
Empowering communities to exercise their own rights and increase their influence on local policies and resource allocation; promoting an accountable civil society which is able to drive pro-poor policies and equitable change. Building a responsive local government which can respond to the priorities of its people, engaging networks of communities, civil society and local government in order to work with a widerange of national and international actors. Increasing the participation of women in society, helping them to gain positions of leadership and to participate in decision making processes at all levels. Working towards a pro-poor private sector to ensure the private sector and the government adopt business practices and policies which benefit poor and vulnerable people.
To achieve our goals, the Oxfam Country strategy focuses on three thematic areas of work: Governance and Social Accountability, Economic Justice, and Humanitarian. Gender Equality is a core element in all programs, ensuring that we put women at the centre of everything we do.
